thread.title: Photo of 'wet patch' on Mars could show water flowing on red planet a year before NASA knew -
thread.title_full: Photo of 'wet patch' on Mars could show water flowing on red planet a year before NASA knew - Mirror Online

author: Jeff Parsons
title: Photo of 'wet patch' on Mars could show water flowing on red planet a year before NASA knew -
text:
The surface of Mars has played host to cutlery , scorpions and a Buddha in recent months - but one thing we know for sure is there's water on the Red Planet somewhere.
Now a startling picture appears to show running liquid in the Martian dust - and NASA didn't spot it.
A small patch of what looks like wet dirt can clearly be seen in this picture from the Mars Curiosity Rover.
The picture was taken on August 2, 2014 - more than a year before NASA announced it had found water.
It was spotted by a UFO enthusiast who has seen plenty of extraordinary things on Mars.
"In this photo, I found water running down from below the rocks on a small two metre tall hillside in Gale Crater," said Scott C Waring, the editor of UFO Sightings Daily and the man who spotted the damp patch.
NASA Do you believe this photo shows running water on Mars?
"You can see the wetness and the different colour of soil compared to that around it," he told the Express .
"There is no doubt that it is water."
Last month, NASA confirmed that shallow streaks of water had been spotted, via satellite, on the planet's surface.
The streaks were less than 16 feet wide and experts believe they leave behind salt deposits.
These streaks appear on slopes during the Martian summer, when temperatures soar to above -23C and then disappear when it become bitterly cold in winter...sometimes as low as -87C.
PA Photograph received from the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) shows the planet Mars in an image taken by the ISRO Mars Orbiter Mission (MOM) spacecraft
Where the water has come from is still an mystery.
Much of Mars’ water is believed to have evaporated into space, but some remains locked in the polar icecaps and possibly in pockets underground.
Theories include melting of near-surface ice, absorption from the thin Martian atmosphere, and seasonal discharges from water-bearing rock.
Mr Waring may well have stumbled upon photographic evidence of that last one, or it could simply be a shadow.
